Questions.QuestionString: The fuel storage system includes:
Answers: Tanks and tanks venting system,
Tanks and tanks pressurize system,
Tanks, tanks venting system and tanks pressurize system.

Questions.QuestionString: The primary function of storage system is:
Answers: To store fuel,
To store fuel and keep the tanks internal pressure near the ambient air pressure,
To store fuel and keep the tanks always pressurized.

Questions.QuestionString: The vent/surge tanks are located:
Answers: Outboard of the wing tanks,
Inboard of the wing tanks,
In each wing tank.

Questions.QuestionString: The LP (Low Pressure) fuel valves are controlled open if:
Answers: The engine fire pushbutton is selected,
The engine master switch is ON and the engine fire pushbutton is selected,
The engine master switch is ON and the engine fire pushbutton is not selected.

Questions.QuestionString: The function of the cross-feed system is to:
Answers: Let engine 1 or engine 2 have fuel supplied from left wing tank, right wing tank or center tank,
Isolate the left and right side of the engine feed gallery,
All above.

Questions.QuestionString: What is correct statement for two cross-feed valves in cross-feed system?
Answers: The two cross-feed valves are connected in parallel on the engine feed gallery,
The two cross-feed valves are both closed during normal operation and are controlled by their applicable P/BSWs,
Both a and b are correct.

Questions.QuestionString: The cross-feed valves are located:
Answers: In the center tank,
In the left wing tank,
In the right wing tank.

Questions.QuestionString: During normal operation. The APU receives fuel from:
Answers: The left wing tank, if the engine feed pumps are OFF,
The center tank, if the engine feed pumps are OFF,
The right wing tank, if the engine feed pumps are OFF.

Questions.QuestionString: The APU fuel pump operates with APU isolation valve and APU low pressure valve open if:
Answers: The APU MASTER SWITCH is set to ON,
The APU START P/BSW is set to ON,
The APU MASTER SWITCH is set to ON and there is no selection of the APU emergency shutdown.

Questions.QuestionString: What is correct statement for location of the APU fuel pump, APU isolation valve and APU low pressure valve?
Answers: The APU fuel pump and APU isolation valve are located in the center tank. The APU low pressure valve is located in front of the APU compartment,
The APU fuel pump and APU low pressure valve are located in the center tank. The APU isolation valve is located in front of the APU compartment,
The APU fuel pump and APU isolation valve are located in the center tank. The APU low pressure valve is located on the APU.

Questions.QuestionString: The primary function of the FQMS (Fuel Quantity and Management System) includes:
Answers: Fuel quantity measurement, fuel temperature measurement, fuel specific levels measurement and Fuel system management,
Fuel quantity measurement and Fuel system management,
Fuel quantity measurement, fuel specific levels measurement and Fuel system management.

Questions.QuestionString: The FQMS (Fuel Quantity and Management System) includes:
Answers: Tank sensors, three TWDC (Tank Wall Data Concentrator) and the IRP (Integrated Refuel Panel),
The primary fuel application software hosted in CPIOMs (Core Processing Input / Output Modules),
Both a and b.

Questions.QuestionString: Function of the TWDCs (Tank Wall Data Concentrators) is:
Answers: Change the sensors analogue signals to digital signals,
Calculate the fuel quantity,
a

Questions.QuestionString: The TWDCs (Tank Wall Data Concentrators) are located:
Answers: On the rear spar of the wings tanks and center tank,
In the forward cargo compartment,
In the avionic compartment.

Questions.QuestionString: The function of the detection system is to monitor:
Answers: The different pressurized compartments and areas of the aircraft for smoke and/or fire,
The different unpressurized compartments and areas of the aircraft for smoke and/or fire,
The different pressurized and unpressurized compartments and areas of the aircraft for smoke and/or fire.

Questions.QuestionString: If there is smoke, the smoke detectors send signals to:
Answers: The SDF (Smoke Detection Function) which is a partition of the CIDS (Cabin Intercommunication Data System,
The SDF (Smoke Detection Function) application hosted in the CPIOMs (Core Processing Input / Output Modules),
The SDCU (Smoke Detector Control Unit).

Questions.QuestionString: The fire detectors are installed in the unpressurized areas that follow:
Answers: APU (Auxiliary Power Unit) and engines,
APU (Auxiliary Power Unit), MLGB (Main Landing Gear Bay) and engines,
APU (Auxiliary Power Unit), MLGB (Main Landing Gear Bay), NLGB (Nose Landing Gear Bay) and engines.

Questions.QuestionString: If there is a fire, the fire detectors send signals through conversion modules to:
Answers: The Fire Protection Function (FPF) which is an application hosted in the Core Processing Input/Output Module (CPIOM),
The Fire Protection Function (FPF) which is an application hosted in the Cabin Intercommunication Data System (CIDS),
The Fire Protection Unit (FPU).

Questions.QuestionString: The fire detectors send signals to FPF (Fire Protection Function) through:
Answers: Conversion Modules,
CRDCs (Common Remote Data Concentrators),
FDUs (Fire Detector Units).

Questions.QuestionString: The FPF (Fire Protection Function) get ground signal from LGERS (Landing Gear Extension Retraction System) application hosted in the CPIOMs (Core Processing Input / Output Modules) to:
Answers: Generate APU FIRE warning that are applicable on the ground,
Perform BITE test of the APU FIRE DETECTION system,
Inhibited the aural warning from external horn and visual warning from APU fire light on nose landing gear.

Questions.QuestionString: For FPF (Fire Protection Function). The number of CM (Conversion Module) are:
Answers: Two: One for engine 1 and APU, One for engine 2 and MLGB (Main Landing Gear Bay),
Three: One for engine 1, one for engine 2 and one for APU and MLGB (Main Landing Gear Bay),
Four: One for engine 1, one for engine 2, one for APU and one for MLGB (Main Landing Gear Bay).

Questions.QuestionString: The APU fire extinguishing system is controlled:
Answers: Manually, through the operation of the APU FIRE, then of the FIRE/APU/AGENT pushbutton switches,
Automatically on ground through the FPF (Fire Protection Function) hosted in the CPIOM (Core Processing Input / Output Modules),
Both a and b.

Questions.QuestionString: Number of cargo fire extinghuishing bottles is/are:
Answers: Two high-rate fire-extinguisher bottles,
Two: One high-rate fire-extinguisher bottle and flow-metered fire-extinguisher bottle,
Two flow-metered fire-extinguisher bottles.

Questions.QuestionString: The air intake system supplies ambient air to:
Answers: The APU engine,
The APU compartment cooling and ventilation,
The APU engine and also supplies the air for the APU compartment cooling and ventilation.

Questions.QuestionString: The air intake flap of APU:
Answers: Points forward  when it opens and has two different open positions for operation on ground or during flight,
Points aft  when it opens and has two different open positions for operation on ground or during flight,
Points forward when it opens and has one open position for all time operation.

Questions.QuestionString: The air intake system supplies ambient air:
Answers: To the APU engine,
For the APU compartment cooling and ventilation,
To the APU engine. It also supplies the air for the APU compartment cooling and ventilation.

Questions.QuestionString: Function of exhaust system of the APU is:
Answers: To releases the APU engine exhaust gas,
To decreases the noise,
To releases the APU engine exhaust gas and decreases the noise.

Questions.QuestionString: The engine system of APU includes:
Answers: The power section, the load compressor and the accessory drive gearbox,
The engine fuel and control system, the engine controls system and the oil system,
The turbine section, the load compressor and the accessory drive gearbox.

Questions.QuestionString: The power section of the APU engine system has:
Answers: A load compressor, a combustion chamber and a turbine,
A accessory drive gearbox, a combustion chamber and a turbine,
A compressor assembly, a combustion chamber and a turbine.

Questions.QuestionString: The power section supplies mechanical power to:
Answers: The load compressor,
The accessory drive gearbox,
The load compressor and the accessory drive gearbox.

Questions.QuestionString: The power section of the APU engine system. It is:
Answers: A single shaft gas turbine,
A dual shaft gas turbine,
A triple shaft gas turbine.

Questions.QuestionString: The load compressor supplies compressed air. It is:
Answers: A centrifugal compressor type with adjustable Inlet Guide Vanes (IGVs),
A centrifugal compressor type with adjustable Outlet Guide Vanes (OGVs),
An axial flow compressor type with adjustable Inlet Guide Vanes (IGVs).

Questions.QuestionString: Which accessories are operated by the accessory drive gearbox of APU engine system?
Answers: The FCU (Fuel Control Unit), the oil pump assembly or starter generator,
The FCU (Fuel Control Unit), IGVs (Inlet Guide Vanes) or starter generator,
The FCU (Fuel Control Unit), starter motor or generator.

Questions.QuestionString: The APU oil system lubricates and decreases the temperature of:
Answers: The APU bearings,
The starter generator,
The APU bearings, the gears and the starter generator.

Questions.QuestionString: The main components of APU oil system are:
Answers: An oil tank and an oil pump assembly,
An oil tank and an air/oil cooler,
An oil tank, an oil pump assembly and an air/oil cooler.

Questions.QuestionString: For the APU oil system. Which components are installed on the accessory gearbox?
Answers: The oil tank and the oil pump assembly,
The oil tank and the air/oil cooler,
The oil tank, the oil pump assembly and the air/oil cooler.

Questions.QuestionString: The APU oil system is cooled by:
Answers: Fuel,
Air,
Fuel and air.

Questions.QuestionString: The APU air system includes:
Answers: The bleed and surge air system,
The accessory cooling system,
The bleed and surge air system and the accessory cooling system.

Questions.QuestionString: For APU air system. The ECB (Electronic Control Box) controls:
Answers: The APU bleed valve and the surge control valve,
The IGVs (Inlet Guide Vanes) and the surge control valve,
The APU bleed valve, the IGVs (Inlet Guide Vanes) and the surge control valve.

Questions.QuestionString: The engine fuel and control system for APU includes:
Answers: The fuel supply system and the fuel distribution system,
The fuel supply system and the fuel control and monitoring system,
The fuel distribution system and the fuel control and monitoring system.

Questions.QuestionString: The APU FCU (Fuel Control Unit) is the primary component of the engine fuel and control system. The FCU supplies the pressurized fuel:
Answers: To the combustion chamber,
To the IGVs (Inlet Guide Vanes), the surge control valve and the bleed valve actuators,
Both a and b.

Questions.QuestionString: The APU ignition system includes:
Answers: One ignition unit supplies high voltage to one igniter plug,
One ignition unit supplies high voltage to two igniter plugs,
Two ignition units supplies high voltage to one igniter plug.

Questions.QuestionString: For APU ignition and starting system. There is one SGCU (Starter-Generator Control Unit) and one SPU (Starter Power Unit). They are installed:
Answers: In APU compartment,
In avionic compartment,
In APU compartment for SPU and in avionic compartment for SGCU.

Questions.QuestionString: The engine thrust transmitted to the pylon by:
Answers: Fwd mount of engine mount assembly,
Aft  mount of engine mount assembly,
Two thrust links through the aft mount.

Questions.QuestionString: The primary components of engine are:
Answers: Low Pressure (LP) spool (N1), Intermediate Pressure (IP) spool (N2) and High Pressure (HP) spool (N3),
A Low Pressure Compressor (LPC) compressor, An Intermediate Pressure Compressor (IPC) assembly and A High Pressure Compressor (HPC),
A Low Pressure Turbine (LPT), an Intermediate Pressure Turbine (IPT) and a High Pressure Turbine (HPT).

Questions.QuestionString: The PCS (Propulsion Control System) gives control for:
Answers: Engine starting, shutdown functions,
Power management and engine indicating/monitoring functions,
Engine starting, shutdown, power management and engine indicating/monitoring functions.

Questions.QuestionString: The PCS (Propulsion Control System) includes:
Answers: EIF (Engine Interface Unit), EEC (Engine Electronic Controller) and EMU (Engine Monitoring Unit),
EIF (Engine Interface Unit), EEC (Engine Electronic Controller) and ETRAC (Electronic Thrust Reverser Actuation Controller),
EIF, EEC, EMU and ETRAC.

Questions.QuestionString: The EEC (Engine Electronic Controller) supplied by:
Answers: PMA (Permanent Magnet Alternator),
The aircraft electrical network,
The PMA (Permanent Magnet Alternator) when the engine is running and by the aircraft electrical network when engine is not running.

Questions.QuestionString: Where are the location of EEC (Engine Electronic Controller) and EMU (Engine Monitoring Unit)?
Answers: The EEC is on the left side of the fan case and the EMU is on the right side of the fan case,
The EEC and the EMU are on the left side of the fan case,
The EEC is on the right side of the fan case and the EMU is on the left side of the fan case,

Questions.QuestionString: Where is the location of EEC PMA (Permanent Magnet Alternator)?
Answers: On the left side of the fan case,
On the gearbox,
On the right side of the fan case.

Questions.QuestionString: Where is the location of the engine fuel pump?
Answers: On  the left side of the fan case,
On the external gearbox,
On the right side of the fan case.

Questions.QuestionString: Where is the location of the FOHE (Fuel/Oil Heat Exchanger)?
Answers: On the fan case,
On the external gearbox,
On the pylon.

Questions.QuestionString: Where is the location of the HMU (Hydro-Mechanical Unit)?
Answers: On the fan case,
On the external gearbox,
On the pylon.

Questions.QuestionString: The manual thrust demand is transmitted from the throttle control levers to the EEC (Engine Electronic Controller) through:
Answers: The PRIMs (Primary computers),
The EIF (Engine Interface Function) application,
The PRIMs and the EIF application.

Questions.QuestionString: Engine air system includes:
Answers: Compressor control and Engine Section Stator (ESS) anti-icing,
Cooling and Engine Section Stator (ESS) anti-icing,
Compressor control, Cooling and Engine Section Stator (ESS) anti-icing.

Questions.QuestionString: The number of IP (Intermediate Pressure) bleed valves and HP (High Pressure) bleed valves on each engine are:
Answers: Three IP bleed valves and three HP bleed valves,
Two IP bleed valves and two HP bleed valves,
Two IP bleed valves and one HP bleed valves.

Questions.QuestionString: The two bleed valve controllers are fitted in:
Answers: Zone 1 (LP compressor case),
Zone 2 (IP compressor case),
Zone 3 (HP compressor case).

Questions.QuestionString: The compressor airflow control system is controlled by:
Answers: The EEC (Engine Electronic Controller),
The two bleed valves controllers,
The EMU (Engine Monitoring Unit).

Questions.QuestionString: The space between the engine cowls and the engine case has three zones. The zone 1 is:
Answers: Annular space between the IP (Intermediate Pressure) compressor case and the gas generator fairings,
Annular space between the fan case and the fan cowls,
Annular space between the core engine and the T/R (Thrust Reverser) cowls.

Questions.QuestionString: The space between the engine cowls and the engine case has three zones. The zone 2 is:
Answers: Annular space between the IP (Intermediate Pressure) compressor case and the gas generator fairings,
Annular space between the fan case and the fan cowls,
Annular space between the core engine and the T/R (Thrust Reverser) cowls.

Questions.QuestionString: The space between the engine cowls and the engine case has three zones. The zone 3 is:
Answers: Annular space between the IP (Intermediate Pressure) compressor case and the gas generator fairings,
Annular space between the fan case and the fan cowls,
Annular space between the core engine and the T/R (Thrust Reverser) cowls.

Questions.QuestionString: The LPTCC (Low Pressure Turbine Case Cooling) valve is operated:
Answers: Through the right bleed valve controller using HPC (High Pressure Compressor) air pressure,
Through the left bleed valve controller using HPC (High Pressure Compressor) air pressure,
Through the TCC (Turbine Case Cooling) actuators controlled by the HMU (Hydro-Mechanical Unit).

Questions.QuestionString: The IPTCC (Intermediate Pressure Turbine Case Cooling) and HPTCC (High Pressure Turbine Case Cooling) valves are operated:
Answers: Through the right bleed valve controller using HPC (High Pressure Compressor) air pressure,
Through the left bleed valve controller using HPC (High Pressure Compressor) air pressure,
Through the TCC (Turbine Case Cooling) actuators controlled by the HMU (Hydro-Mechanical Unit).

Questions.QuestionString: The EEC (Engine Electronic Controller) controls the Engine Section Stator (ESS) anti-icing valve to supply hot air from:
Answers: The last (eighth) stage of the IP (Intermediate Pressure) compressor to the inlet of the IPC (Intermediate Pressure) compressor,
The LP (Low Pressure) compressor,
The HP (High Pressure) compressor.

Questions.QuestionString: The Engine Section Stator (ESS) anti-icing valve is operated:
Answers: Through the right bleed valve controller using air pressure from the HPC (High Pressure Compressor),
Through the right bleed valve controller using air pressure from the HPC (High Pressure Compressor),
Through the Engine Section Stator (ESS) actuator controlled by the HMU (Hydro-Mechanical Unit).

Questions.QuestionString: The Engine Section Stator (ESS) anti-icing valve is installed in:
Answers: Zone 1 (LP compressor case),
Zone 2 (IP compressor case),
Zone 3 (HP compressor case).

Questions.QuestionString: Which valve is operated through the right bleed valve controller using air pressure from the HP compressor?
Answers: The Low Pressure Turbine Case Cooling (LPTCC) valve and the ESS (Engine Section Stator) anti-icing valve,
The Intermediate Pressure Turbine Case Cooling (IPTCC) valve and the ESS (Engine Section Stator) anti-icing valve,
The High Pressure Turbine Case Cooling (HPTCC) valve and the ESS (Engine Section Stator) anti-icing valve,

Questions.QuestionString: Each engine has two ignition systems. These system can operate:
Answers: Together,
Independently,
Together or Independently.

Questions.QuestionString: The electrical power supply to the ignition units is controlled by:
Answers: The EIF (Engine Interface Function), hosted on CPIOMs (Core Processing Input / Output Modules),
The EEC (Engine Electronic Controller),
The EMU (Engine Monitoring Unit).

Questions.QuestionString: Each ignition system has:
Answers: One ignition unit and one igniter plug,
One ignition unit and two igniter plug,
One exciter and one igniter plug.

Questions.QuestionString: For the ignition system:
Answers: The ignition units are on the left side of the fan case,
The igniter plugs are installed on the combustion chamber,
Both a and b.

Questions.QuestionString: The function of the oil system is to lubricate and supply sufficient oil at a correct temperature and pressure to following engine internal components:
Answers: Drives,
Bearings,
Drives, Gears and Bearings.

Questions.QuestionString: The oil system includes:
Answers: Oil storage and oil distribution,
Oil distribution and Oil indication (quantity, pressure and temperature),
Oil storage, Oil distribution and Oil indication (quantity, pressure and temperature).

Questions.QuestionString: The T/R (Thrust reverser) system are:
Answers: Electrically controlled and hydraulically operated,
Đáp án 1
Đáp án 2

Questions.QuestionString: For operate the translating cowls of the T/R (Thrust reverser) system. There are:
Answers: One electric motor, two flex synchro shafts and three actuators per side,
Two electric motors, two flex synchro shafts and three actuators per side,
One electric motors, two flex synchro shafts and two actuators per side,

Questions.QuestionString: The ETRACs (Electronic Thrust Reverser Actuation Controller) are installed:
Answers: In the forward cargo compartment,
In the avionic compartment,
On the related pylon.

Questions.QuestionString: The primary engine parameters shown on the ED (Engine Display) are:
Answers: THR (%), N1 (%) and EGT (0C),
EPR, N1 (%) and EGT (0C),
THR (%), N1 (%), FF (KG/H or LBS/H) and EGT (0C).

Questions.QuestionString: The pneumatic system is monitored for:
Answers: Leaks,
Pressure and temperature,
Leaks, pressure and temperature.

Questions.QuestionString: Engine bleed-air pressure is regulated by:
Answers: The pressure sensor feedback controls the MPV (Manifold Pressure Valve) through the remote servo to get the bleed demand,
The BAS (Bleed Air System) application hosted in CPIOMs (Core Processing Input / Output Modules),
The bleed valve controllers.

Questions.QuestionString: Engine bleed-air temperature is regulated by:
Answers: The pressure sensor feedback controls the FAV (Fan Air Valve) through the remote servo to modulate the fan airflow through the Precooler (PCE),
The BAS (Bleed Air System) application hosted in CPIOMs (Core Processing Input / Output Modules),
The bleed valve controllers.

Questions.QuestionString: The OPSOV (Overpressure Shut-off Valve) is:
Answers: In the engine core zone,
In the pylon zone, downstream of the PCE (Pre-cooler),
In the pylon zone, upstream of the PCE (Pre-cooler).

Questions.QuestionString: To prevents the airflow back into the APU. This is function of:
Answers: The APU bleed valve,
The APU check valve is part of the APU bleed duct,
The cross bleed valve.

Questions.QuestionString: In normal mode, the cross bleed valve is controlled by:
Answers: The BAS (Bleed Air System) application on CPIOMs (Core Processing Input / Output Modules) through the BOMUs (Bleed and Overheat Monitoring Unit),
The BOMUs (Bleed and Overheat Monitoring Unit) from the ICP (Integrated Control Panel),
The ECB (Electronic Control Box) through the BOMUs (Bleed and Overheat Monitoring Unit).

Questions.QuestionString: General familiarization training for air conditioning system focus on:
Answers: The air cooling system, the temperature control system and the pressure control and monitoring system,
The air cooling system, the distribution system and the temperature control system,
The air cooling system, the distribution system, the temperature control system and the pressure control and monitoring system.

Questions.QuestionString: The air cooling system supplies cool and fresh air to:
Answers: The passengers, crew and food storage areas,
The passengers, crew, equipment cooling and Fuel Tank Inerting System (FTIS),
The passengers, crew, food storage areas, equipment cooling and Fuel Tank Inerting System (FTIS).

Questions.QuestionString: The ozone control system:
Answers: Decreases the concentration of ozone in the hot bleed air,
Increases the concentration of ozone in the hot bleed air,
Decreases the concentration of ozone in the cooling air.

Questions.QuestionString: The number of FCV (Flow Control Valve) on each air conditioning pack are:
Answers: One FCV (Flow Control Valve) for each pack,
Two FCVs (Flow Control Valves) for each pack that installed in parallel,
Two FCVs (Flow Control Valves) for each pack that installed in series.

Questions.QuestionString: When the pack pushbutton switches are pushed, the FCVs (Flow Control Valves) are controlled and monitored by:
Answers: The ASCUs (Air Systems Control Units),
The ACSs (Air Conditioning System) applications on the CPIOMs (Core Processing Input / Output Modules),
The ASCUs and the ACSs applications on the CPIOMs.

Questions.QuestionString: The ASCUs (Air Systems Control Units) installed in:
Answers: The avionic compartment,
The Forward cargo compartment,
The air conditioning compartment.

Questions.QuestionString: The emergency air supply system is monitored by:
Answers: The ASCUs (Air Systems Control Units),
The ACSs (Air Conditioning System) applications on the CPIOMs (Core Processing Input / Output Modules),
The CPCS (Cabin Pressure Control System) applications.

Questions.QuestionString: The emergency air supply system is automatically controlled by:
Answers: The ASCUs (Air Systems Control Units),
The ACSs (Air Conditioning System) applications on the CPIOMs (Core Processing Input / Output Modules),
The CPCS (Cabin Pressure Control System) applications.

Questions.QuestionString: Each CSAS (Conditioned Service Air System) operates:
Answers: Automatically in flight,
Automatically on ground,
Automatically in flight and on ground.

Questions.QuestionString: The pressure and temperature of the bleed air that is supplied to the IGGS (Inert Gas Generating System) are controlled by:
Answers: A turbo compressor and a heat exchanger,
The ASCUs (Air Systems Control Units),
The ACSs (Air Conditioning System) applications on the CPIOMs (Core Processing Input / Output Modules),

Questions.QuestionString: In the basic configuration, the SCS (Supplemental Cooling System) has:
Answers: Two VCRUs (Vapor Cycle Refrigeration Units) and ACUs (Air Cooling Units),
Two VCRUs (Vapor Cycle Refrigeration Units) and a CDM (Coolant Distribution Module),
Two VCRUs (Vapor Cycle Refrigeration Units), a CDM (Coolant Distribution Module) and ACUs (Air Cooling Units).

Questions.QuestionString: The CSASs (Conditioned Service Air Systems) are controlled and monitored by:
Answers: The related ASCUs (Air Systems Control Units),
The ACSs (Air Conditioning System) applications on the CPIOMs (Core Processing Input / Output Modules),
The related ASCUs and the CPIOM ACS applications.

Questions.QuestionString: The VCRUs (Vapor Cycle Refrigeration Unit) and the CDMs (Coolant Distribution Module) are installed in:
Answers: The aft belly fairing,
The avionic compartment,
The forward cargo compartment.

Questions.QuestionString: The avionics equipment ventilation-system has:
Answers: A left blowing subsystem, a right blowing subsystem and an extraction subsystem,
A blowing subsystem and an extraction subsystem,
A left blowing subsystem, a right blowing subsystem.

Questions.QuestionString: The TCS (Temperature Control System) includes:
Answers: The temperature control and monitoring system and the galley-area supplementary-heating system,
The temperature control and monitoring system and the lower-deck cargo-compartment temperature-control and monitor system,
The temperature control and monitoring system, the galley-area supplementary-heating system and the lower-deck cargo-compartment temperature-control and monitor system.

Questions.QuestionString: The TCS (Temperature Control System) controls and monitors the temperature in:
Answers: In the cabin and in the galleys compartments,
In the cabin, in the galleys and in the lavatories compartments,
In the cabin, in the galleys and in the cargo compartments.

Questions.QuestionString: The bulk cargo compartment is heated by:
Answers: Hot air from pneumatic system,
An electrical heater increases the temperature of the air that comes from the cabin distribution system,
Both a and b.

Questions.QuestionString: In auto mode the position of the OFVs (Out Flow Valves) are controlled by:
Answers: The OCUs (Out Flow Valve Control Units),
The SACU (Semi-Automatic Control Unit),
The CPIOM (Core Processing Input / Output Module) CPCS (Cabin Pressure Control System) applications through the OCUs (Out Flow Valve Control Units).

Questions.QuestionString: The pressure control and monitoring system has:
Answers: Two Outflow Valves (OFVs), two Outflow Valve Control Units (OCUs), a Semi-Automatic Control Unit (SACU), an overpressure relief valve and two negative relief valves,
Two Outflow Valves (OFVs), one Outflow Valve Control Unit (OCU), two Semi-Automatic Control Units (SACUs), an overpressure relief valve and two negative relief valves,
Two Outflow Valves (OFVs), two Outflow Valve Control Units (OCUs), a Semi-Automatic Control Unit (SACU), an negative relief valve and two safety valves.

Questions.QuestionString: In manual mode the OFVs (Out Flow Valves) are controlled by:
Answers: The OCUs (Out Flow Valve Control Units),
The SACU (Semi-Automatic Control Unit),
Selection on the CABIN PRESS panel.

Questions.QuestionString: The function of the Inert gas system is:
Answers: To decrease oxygen concentration in fuel tanks for safety,
To decrease nitrogen concentration in fuel tanks for safety,
To increase oxygen concentration in fuel tanks for safety.

Questions.QuestionString: The function of the IGGS (Inert Gas Generation System) is to decrease tanks flammability exposure with generation of:
Answers: NEA (Nitrogen Enriched Air),
OEA (Oxygen Enriched Air),
HEA (Hydro Enriched Air).

Questions.QuestionString: The two ASM (Air Separation Module) pallets are installed:
Answers: One in each side wall of forward cargo compartment,
In belly fairing air conditioning compartment,
One in each wing leading edge.

Questions.QuestionString: The NEA (Nitrogen Enriched Air) flow to fuel tanks are controlled by:
Answers: DFSOVs (Dual Flow Shut-Off Valves),
TIVs (Temperature Isolation Valves),
IGDS (Inert Gas Distribution System).

Questions.QuestionString: The Inert Gas System operates:
Answers: In flight only,
On ground only,
In flight and on ground.

Questions.QuestionString: In flight, the WIPS (Wing Ice Protection System) supplies hot air from the engine bleed-air system to three slats on each wing. The three slats are:
Answers: Slat No 1, 2, 3,
Slat No 3, 4, 5,
Slat No 5, 6, 7.

Questions.QuestionString: The operation mode of WIPS (Wing Ice Protection System) is:
Answers: Manually,
Automatically,
Automatically and manually.

Questions.QuestionString: The WIPS (Wing Ice Protection System) is controlled and monitored by:
Answers: The  WIPS (Wing Ice Protection System) application hosted in two CPIOMs (Core Processing Input / Output Modules),
Two BAS (Bleed Air System) application hosted in two CPIOMs (Core Processing Input / Output Modules),
The WIPS application hosted in two CPIOMs and two BOMUs.

Questions.QuestionString: The engine air intake ice protection system supplies hot air from the HPC (High Pressure Compressor) to the inlet lip of the air intake. The hot air is supplied through:
Answers: A pressure-regulating and shutoff valve,
A Pressure regulating valve,
A pressure-regulating and shutoff valve and a pressure regulating valve.

Questions.QuestionString: The ice protection of each engine is controlled and monitored by:
Answers: Related EEC (Engine Electronic Controller),
An AICF-NAI (Anti Ice Control Function – Nacelle Anti Icing) application,
An AICF-NAI application through an EEC.

Questions.QuestionString: The Rain Repellent System can operate when:
Answers: Aircraft in flight,
Aircraft network energized,
WHC1 and WHC 2 receive an engine running signal from the EIF application.

Questions.QuestionString: The fluid level of rain repellent is monitored by,
Answers: WHC 1 (Window Heat Computer),
WHC 2 (Window Heat Computer),
WHC 1 and WHC 2.

Questions.QuestionString: The water-line ice-protection system has:
Answers: Ice Protection Control Units (IPCUs), temperature sensors and electrical heating elements,
Temperature sensors and electrical heating elements,
Ice Protection Control Units (IPCUs) and electrical heating elements.
